search_matches.text:
NEW PAGE 16
CHAPTER 4: ZONING DISTRICTS
Section 4.0 Primary Use Districts
This Chapter establishes zoning districts and identifies the uses that are permitted within each
district. In accordance with the requirement of NCGS 160D-703 that zoning regulation be by
districts, the Town, as shown on the Zoning Map accompanying this Ordinance, is hereby divided
into the following districts which shall be governed by all of the uniform use and dimensional
requirements of this Ordinance.
The Primary Use Districts are outlined from Section 4.1 to Section 4.8. Each section includes a
description of the district and its intent, a chart with the most common uses permitted in the district,
a chart that lists the dimensional requirements and a list of additional requirements and their
location in the ordinance.
Section 4.1
R-A Residential Agricultural District
Section 4.1.1 Intent
The regulations of this district are intended to encourage the continuance of agricultural uses as
well as to insure that residential development NOT having access to public water supplies and
dependent upon septic tanks for sewage disposal will occur at a sufficiently low density to provide
a healthful environment.
Table 4.1 Dimensional Requirements in the R-A District
*
If the property lies within the Hunting Creek Watershed, the minimum lot size is 25,000 square feet per
dwelling unit.
Section 4.1.2 Other Requirements
A. Uses. See the Tables of Permitted and Special Uses in Section 4.11.
B. Locations of Accessory Buildings. Accessory buildings and structures shall be placed in
accordance with the provisions of Section 3.9.
C. Off-Street Parking. Off-street parking shall be provided in accordance with the requirements
in Chapter 6.
D. Signs. Signs shall be regulated by the requirements in Section 11.
E. Landscaping. Landscaping shall be provided in accordance with the requirements in Chapter
8.
F. Performance Requirements. Performance requirements apply as specified in Chapter 5.
Section 4.1.3 Uses
The chart below indicates the common uses generally permitted in the RA zoning district. For
a complete table of permitted uses see Section 8:
11

NEW PAGE 18
Section 4.2
RU-R Rural Residential District
Section 4.2.1 Intent
The regulations of this district are intended to ensure that residential development NOT having
access to public utilities will occur at sufficiently low densities to maintain and promote a rural
and semi-rural atmosphere, as well as to encourage the continuance of agricultural uses appropriate
to a rural residential area.
Table 4.3 Dimensional Requirements in the RU-R District
* If the property lies within the Hunting Creek Watershed, the minimum lot size is 25,000 square feet per
dwelling unit.
Section 4.2.2 Other Requirements
A. Uses. See the Tables of Permitted and Special Uses in Section 4.11.
B. Locations of Accessory Buildings. Accessory buildings and structures shall be placed in
accordance with the provisions of Section 3.9.
C. Off-Street Parking. Off-street parking shall be provided in accordance with the requirements
in Chapter 6.
D. Signs. Signs shall be regulated by the requirements in Section 11.
E. Landscaping. Landscaping shall be provided in accordance with the requirements in Chapter
8.
F. Performance Requirements. Performance requirements apply as specified in Chapter 5.
Section 4.2.3 Uses
The chart below indicates the common uses generally permitted in the RUR zoning district. For
a complete table of permitted uses see Section 8:
Table 4.4 More Common Uses Permitted in the RU-R District

search_matches.text:
NEW PAGE 15
Industrial Buildings
1. Front façades or industrial buildings shall be primarily brick, stucco, stone, decorative
concrete clock or other materials similar in appearance and durability. Standards concrete
block, case concrete and metal may be used as minority elements (max of 50 percent) on
the front façade. All accessory buildings shall be clad in materials similar in appearance
to the principal structure.
2. Pitched roofs shall be clad in standing seam metal, long span metal panels, slate, asphalt
shingles or similar material.
3.
Flat roofs shall incorporate parapet walls to conceal the flat portions of the roof elevations
that are visible from any public street. Parapet walls shall screen roof-top mechanical
equipment from the street.
10

search_matches.text:
NEW PAGE 14
5. Two wall materials may be combined horizontally on one façade, the heavier material
should be below.
6. Decorative concrete block, siding, exterior insulation finishing systems (EIFS), and other
minority elements may be used as an accent material only (less than 25 percent of the
façade)
7. Pitched roofs should be clad in wood shingles, standing seam metal, slate, asphalt shingles
or similar materials.
8. Foundation walls (except those under porches) shall be finished with brick or stone. The
crawlspace of porches shall be enclosed with brick, stone, wood lattice, or any combination
thereof.
9. Façade colors shall be of low reflectance earth tone, muted, subtle, or neutral colors.
Building trim may feature brighter colors, Neon, or similar gas tubing, is not allowed as an
accent material. The use of high-intensity or metallic colors is not allowed except for
accent purposes. Fluorescent, day glow, or neon colors shall be prohibited as a primary
wall color. Variations in color schemes are encourage in order to articulate entryways and
public amenities SO as to give great recognition to these features.
10. All accessory buildings shall be clad in materials similar in appearance to the principal
structure.
Configuration
1. Roof pitches less than 3/12 and flat roofs will require a parapet wall.
2.
Pitched roof shall be profiled by leaves and gable overhangs a minimum of 12 inches from
the building face.
3. Flat roofs shall incorporate parapet walls with decorative cornices to conceal the flat
portions of the roof and mechanical equipment that are visible on the front and side
elevations from any public street.
4. At least 40 percent of the length of the first floor on street fronting facades shall be in
windows or doorways for the principal building. Street level windows shall be visually
permeable. Mirrorized glass is not permitted in any locations. Faux or display casements
are not permitted in lieu of exterior window treatments for the frontage elevation.
5. No frontage wall shall have more than 20 linear feet without a transparent window or door
or a significant architectural element. Ventilation grates or emergency exit doors location
at the first color level oriented toward a public street, shall be decorative.
6.
Residential uses in mixed use buildings shall not be located on the street level.
7. When used, awnings and canopies shall be placed at the top of window or doorway
openings. Awnings shall be made of canvas, treated canvas, or similar material. Metal or
vinyl (or plastic) awnings are prohibited. No awning shall extend more than the width of
the sidewalk or ten feet, whichever is less. Awnings must be self-supporting from the wall.
No supports shall rest on or interfere with the use of pedestrian walkways or streets. In no
case shall any awning extend beyond the street curb or interfere with street trees or public
utilities.
8. Canopies shall be of solid material and complement the buildings to which they are affixed
or associated. Gas station canopies must be set back from the property and right-of-way
lines a minimum of the required setback of accessory buildings, as required in the zoning
district where located, and must not interfere with street trees or public unities.
9

NEW PAGE 15
Industrial Buildings
1. Front façades or industrial buildings shall be primarily brick, stucco, stone, decorative
concrete clock or other materials similar in appearance and durability. Standards concrete
block, case concrete and metal may be used as minority elements (max of 50 percent) on
the front façade. All accessory buildings shall be clad in materials similar in appearance
to the principal structure.
2. Pitched roofs shall be clad in standing seam metal, long span metal panels, slate, asphalt
shingles or similar material.
3.
Flat roofs shall incorporate parapet walls to conceal the flat portions of the roof elevations
that are visible from any public street. Parapet walls shall screen roof-top mechanical
equipment from the street.
10

NEW PAGE 19
Section 4.3
R-20 Single-Family Residential District
Section 4.3.1 Intent
The regulations of this district are intended to insure that residential development NOT having
access to public water supplies and dependent upon septic tanks for sewage disposal will occur at
sufficiently low densities to provide a healthful environment.
Table 4.5 Dimensional Requirements in the R-20 District
* If the property lies within the Hunting Creek Watershed, the minimum lot size is 25,000 square feet per
dwelling unit.
Section 4.3.2 Other Requirements
A. Uses. See the Tables of Permitted and Special Uses in Section 4.11.
B. Locations of Accessory Buildings. Accessory buildings and structures shall be placed in
accordance with the provisions of Section 3.9.
C. Off-Street Parking. Off-street parking shall be provided in accordance with the requirements
in Chapter 6.
D. Signs. Signs shall be regulated by the requirements in Section 11.
E. Landscaping. Landscaping shall be provided in accordance with the requirements in Chapter
8.
F. Performance Requirements. Performance requirements apply as specified in Chapter 5.
Section 4.3.3 Uses
The chart below indicates the common uses generally permitted in the R-20 zoning district. For
a complete table of permitted uses see Section 8:
Table 4.6 More Common Uses Permitted in the R-20 District
